course.subject: SCIE
course.name: Guided Study on Research II
course.description: Studies under the directed supervision of a faculty member on a life science / chemistry / environmental science / mathematics / physics topic which serves as the first step in equipping the students with hands-on experience in supervised independent study. An individual written report and/or presentations on a chosen topic are required. For IRE students only.

reviews.author: LukaModric
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1-2 identify a topic and supervisor
Week 3 Submit topic before 20 Feb
Week 4-7 Meeting
Week 8 Submit Progress Report
Week 9-12 Meeting
Week 13 Submit Final Report and Final Presentation
reviews.comment_grading:
Degree of participation (at least 10 meetings): 20%

Quality of preparation demonstrated in the weekly meeting: 20%

Acquisition of literature review ability: 20%

The quality of the progress reports and the final report: 10% +20%
The final presentation (15 min; <20 slides): 10% [presentation would have additional assessor(s)]
reviews.comment_workload:
Format of the Progress Report
NOT exceeding 3 pages and contain the followings:
i. The topic & Personal information (Student’s and Supervisor’s)
ii. A short abstract (~100 words)
iii. A brief account of the background and motivation on why the topic is elected
iv. Review on 1-2 key relevant literature(s), with some supporting articles
     i. Title
     ii. Authors
     iii. Year of publication
     iv. A summary of the major findings (but not simply copying the abstract of the article)
v. Your thoughts and insights gathered after reading the literature(s)
vi. Reference list in American Medical Association (AMA) style

Format of the Final Report
[A mini-review of the topic, assuming that it can be an article to be presented in a newsletter for science students]
NOT exceeding 10 pages and should carry the followings.
i. A specific topic: the same or extended from the one of the progress reports
ii. Personal information (Student’s and Supervisor’s)
iii. A short abstract (~150-250 words)
iv. Background / Introduction
v. Methodology
vi. Main content
vii. Conclusion and Perspective [a key element]
viii. Reference list in AMA style

reviews.author: ggg_
reviews.title: required course for IRE student
reviews.comment_content:
In this course, you need to identify a supervisor, have weekly meetings with him/her, write a progress report, a final literature review and give a final presentation.
The main task is to do literature review on a specific topic, but the content really depends on you and your supervisor.
I am a life science student, so some of my feelings and suggestions may not be applicable to other subjects, but you can take a look if you'd like to.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The workflow really depends on you and your supervisor.
Most of the people I know didn't seem to really meet their supervisors every week. Some of them present papers that they read to their supervisor every two or three weeks, some of them just work with research assistant rather than the professor. As for me, I only met my professor two or three times I think... It is my fault that I didn't save time to read papers and thus had almost nothing to discuss with him or ask him, but he also seems very busy and didn't have time to care... And he forgot the meeting time for two times... Then I proposed maybe it is not necessary to meet every week and I will ask for help when I need to. This is a bad proposal, and the predictable consequence is that I only started reading papers days before the ddl for progress report, and one week before the ddl for final one.
reviews.comment_grading:
Graded by the supervisor on:
degree of participation (at least 10 meetings, 20%)
quality of preparation demonstrated in the weekly meeting (20%)
acquisition of literature review ability (20%)
the quality of the one progress report and the final report. (10% +20%)
The final presentation, 15 min (<20 slides) (10%)

I got A in the end. Seems that everyone gets the same grade, just as in SCIE2500. Maybe most people get A?

Another point is that I was very nervous before the final presentation, partly because I wasn't well-prepared, and also partly because I was afraid the IRE coordinator would criticize my bad work. (Your audience would be your supervisor + IRE coordinator) But it turned out to be ok as they all understand that ug students know nothing about research and didn't have very high expectations, and their questions were not to challenge you.
reviews.comment_workload: Since I only started preparing for the report and presentation no longer than 10 days before the deadline, the workload was super big and I was almost driven crazy. I felt miserable as this course could have brought me more interactions with the professor and more insights into the topic, but I just ended up being a ddl fighter and didn't learn much. I would suggest other students taking this course to fix a literature reading time into your schedule and try your best to meet with your supervisor every week to get the most out of this course. Only by averaging the workload to every day would it be easier. Another suggestion is that please make sure that you summarize what you understood from a paper by a few pages of slides or a short paragraph right after reading it, otherwise you would not be able to recall a single word after several days and you need to read it again before writing. Dividing a large review into several sessions would be very helpful to ease the pressure. (My professor actually provided me with an outline of the review and even the expected finishing time for each section, but sadly I didn't follow it...) And the third suggestion would be -- interact and consult with your supervisor actively as they may be more willing to help and less terrifying than you imagined.

reviews.author: Sonic12
reviews.title: Review of SCIE2500
reviews.comment_content:
This course aims to provide students with better insights for reading thesis and research presentation skills. Provided for IRE track students only.

Week 1~2
: Find your own supervising professor and research topic

Week 4~7
: Weekly meeting with supervisor

Week 8
: Submit progress report

Week 9~12
: Weekly meeting with supervisor

Week 13
: Submit the final report & presentation

It really depends on your research interest and supervisor's style, but overall this course is mostly about thesis review and presentation.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Of course, the teaching can be very different on which professor you choose for a supervisor. I'll write this review solely based on my professor.

In my case, I and my professor both took collaboratively charged with the detailed structure of this course. (which research area to focus on, what contents or topics to put in the reports, what to read etc.)

My professor provided 2 papers every week and I read them, summarized myself, and explained what I understood, and asked questions in the next week's meeting.

As this course is a one-to-one collaborative course with the student and professor, you and your supervisor need to have good chemistry or matching working styles with each other in order to fully engage and learn something meaningful in this course. In my case, it turned out to be quite good and the overall flow of work proceeded flawlessly.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is graded by your supervising professor. So depends on your supervisor's style.

I didn't expect but my professor was very satisfied with my whole understanding of each paper he or she provided.

Submitted both reports in time and I responded supervisor's feedback rapidly.

Overall: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Really depends on how much your supervisor expects from you.

For me 2 papers to read and summarize every week. I don't know how others will feel about this but I was fine with the workload.

The final report submission and presentation might overlap with your preparation for your final exams so work ahead and study diligently.

To add more to the presentation, you'll be presenting your research topic in front of professors and students. Don't be panicked about this, just be yourself, also you need to make ppt simple and concise enough for others to understand your topic as well.

"If you can't explain it simply, you don't understand it well enough"
-Albert Einstein
